elements.content: The quantum spin liquid (QSL) state is of great interest in relation to quantum computation and superconductivity and the search for new QSL materials is a current challenge in chemistry. Existing inorganic and molecular QSL compounds have two-dimensional structures, with spins arranged on triangular and kagome lattices, whereas three-dimensional structures with QSL characteristics are rare. In the copper-oxalate framework compound [(C2H5)3NH]2Cu2(C2O4)3, Cu­(II) is coordinated with three bisbidentate oxalate bridges to form a three-dimensional (10,3) lattice and this produces a strong antiferromagnetic interaction between Cu2+ (S = 1/2) atoms (θ = −180 K). No long-range ordering (LRO) was observed in either magnetic susceptibility or specific heat measurements down to 2 K. Absence of LRO was further confirmed by μSR measurements down to 60 mK, indicating that it is a gapless QSL with f > 3000. Due to Jahn–Teller distortion and partial dimerization, the effective dimensionality of the magnetic lattice is reduced. This compound nevertheless highlights the great potential for obtaining QSLs of varying dimensionality from metal–organic frameworks.
elements.clean_text: The quantum spin liquid (QSL) state is of great interest in relation to quantum computation and superconductivity and the search for new QSL materials is a current challenge in chemistry. Existing inorganic and molecular QSL compounds have two-dimensional structures, with spins arranged on triangular and kagome lattices, whereas three-dimensional structures with QSL characteristics are rare. In the copper-oxalate framework compound [(C2H5)3NH]2Cu2(C2O4)3, Cu(II) is coordinated with three bisbidentate oxalate bridges to form a three-dimensional (10,3) lattice and this produces a strong antiferromagnetic interaction between Cu2+ (S = 1/2) atoms (θ = -180 K). No long-range ordering (LRO) was observed in either magnetic susceptibility or specific heat measurements down to 2 K. Absence of LRO was further confirmed by μSR measurements down to 60 mK, indicating that it is a gapless QSL with f > 3000. Due to Jahn-Teller distortion and partial dimerization, the effective dimensionality of the magnetic lattice is reduced. This compound nevertheless highlights the great potential for obtaining QSLs of varying dimensionality from metal-organic frameworks.

elements.content: The quantum spin liquid (QSL) is an intriguing magnetic phase where spin ordering or freezing is prevented by spin frustration leading to a resonating-valence-bond (RVB) state. Since the RVB state was proposed by P. W. Anderson in 1973 for the two-dimensional triangular lattice, much work has followed, ranging from theory to synthesis. Triangular lattice QSL materials have been discovered in the molecular compounds κ-(BEDT-TTF)2Cu2(CN)3, κ-(BEDT-TTF)2Ag2(CN)3, EtMe3Sb­[Pd­(dmit)2]2 and H3(Cat-EDT-TTF)2, and in the inorganic compounds Ba3CuSb2O9 and YbMgGaO4. Chemists have produced much work on kagome systems, ranging from observation of kagome patterns by STM to synthesis of coordination compounds with kagome magnetic lattices that show LRO, but the first kagome lattice QSL was discovered in ZnCu3(OH)6Cl3 (Herbertsmithite). Two-dimensional honeycomb lattices have risen to great prominence in graphene science, but are also important within quantum magnetism for hosting the famous QSL proposed by Kitaev. However, a stable honeycomb QSL has not yet been achieved, with LRO invariably being found instead, e.g., the inorganic compounds A2IrO3(A = Na, T N = 13 K; A = Li, T N = 15 K) and α-RuCl3 (T N = 8 K) and the molecular compounds with honeycomb anions [CrMn­(C2O4)3 –] n (T c = 5.5 K), [M2(C2O4)3 2–] n (M = Fe, T N = 28 K; M = Co, T N = 21 K). One exception is [(C3H7)3NH]2Cu2(C2O4)3(H2O)2.2, where no LRO was observed down to 2 K with frustration factor f > 60; however, this is accompanied by a dimensional reduction. Meanwhile, moving from a two-dimensional lattice to a three-dimensional lattice, while maintaining the coordination environment, can give a new QSL, as suggested by the hyperkagome lattice derived from the kagome lattice, although in the hyperkagome model compound Na4Ir3O8 spin freezing was found below 6 K. A new hyperkagome system based on S = 1/2 molecular dimers was recently reported, giving the first example of three-dimensional QSL stable to 70 mK. Another candidate QSL system is given by our previously reported three-dimensional copper-oxalate framework compound [(C2H5)3NH]2Cu2(C2O4)3, in which no LRO was observed above 2 K. Further measurements on this compound are reported here covering temperature dependent structure, specific heat and muon spin relaxation in zero applied field.
elements.clean_text: The quantum spin liquid (QSL) is an intriguing magnetic phase where spin ordering or freezing is prevented by spin frustration leading to a resonating-valence-bond (RVB) state. Since the RVB state was proposed by P. W. Anderson in 1973 for the two-dimensional triangular lattice, much work has followed, ranging from theory to synthesis. Triangular lattice QSL materials have been discovered in the molecular compounds κ-(BEDT-TTF)2Cu2(CN)3, κ-(BEDT-TTF)2Ag2(CN)3, EtMe3Sb[Pd(dmit)2]2 and H3(Cat-EDT-TTF)2, and in the inorganic compounds Ba3CuSb2O9 and YbMgGaO4. Chemists have produced much work on kagome systems, ranging from observation of kagome patterns by STM to synthesis of coordination compounds with kagome magnetic lattices that show LRO, but the first kagome lattice QSL was discovered in ZnCu3(OH)6Cl3 (Herbertsmithite). Two-dimensional honeycomb lattices have risen to great prominence in graphene science, but are also important within quantum magnetism for hosting the famous QSL proposed by Kitaev. However, a stable honeycomb QSL has not yet been achieved, with LRO invariably being found instead, e.g., the inorganic compounds A2IrO3(A = Na, T N = 13 K; A = Li, T N = 15 K) and α-RuCl3 (T N = 8 K) and the molecular compounds with honeycomb anions [CrMn(C2O4)3 -] n  (T c = 5.5 K), [M2(C2O4)3 2-] n  (M = Fe, T N = 28 K; M = Co, T N = 21 K). One exception is [(C3H7)3NH]2Cu2(C2O4)3(H2O)2.2, where no LRO was observed down to 2 K with frustration factor f > 60; however, this is accompanied by a dimensional reduction. Meanwhile, moving from a two-dimensional lattice to a three-dimensional lattice, while maintaining the coordination environment, can give a new QSL, as suggested by the hyperkagome lattice derived from the kagome lattice, although in the hyperkagome model compound Na4Ir3O8 spin freezing was found below 6 K. A new hyperkagome system based on S = 1/2 molecular dimers was recently reported, giving the first example of three-dimensional QSL stable to 70 mK. Another candidate QSL system is given by our previously reported three-dimensional copper-oxalate framework compound [(C2H5)3NH]2Cu2(C2O4)3, in which no LRO was observed above 2 K. Further measurements on this compound are reported here covering temperature dependent structure, specific heat and muon spin relaxation in zero applied field.

elements.content: In [(C2H5)3NH]2Cu2(C2O4)3, a three-dimensional copper-oxalate-framework forms a (10,3) lattice (a). The (10,3) lattice is a coordination network isomer of the two-dimensional (6,3) honeycomb lattice and it is an example of a hyperhoneycomb lattice, as found in β-Li2IrO3. There are two crystallographically independent metal atoms with chirality Δ or Λ (b). This is different from the (10,3) lattice in [Mn2(C2O4)3 2–] n with only one enantiomer (Λ). As expected for d9 Cu2+, a Jahn–Teller distortion results in significant elongation of an axial pair of Cu–O bonds in the CuO6 octahedra, which is highlighted by the black solid lines shown in .
elements.clean_text: In [(C2H5)3NH]2Cu2(C2O4)3, a three-dimensional copper-oxalate-framework forms a (10,3) lattice (a). The (10,3) lattice is a coordination network isomer of the two-dimensional (6,3) honeycomb lattice and it is an example of a hyperhoneycomb lattice, as found in β-Li2IrO3. There are two crystallographically independent metal atoms with chirality Δ or Λ (b). This is different from the (10,3) lattice in [Mn2(C2O4)3 2-] n  with only one enantiomer (Λ). As expected for d9 Cu2+, a Jahn-Teller distortion results in significant elongation of an axial pair of Cu-O bonds in the CuO6 octahedra, which is highlighted by the black solid lines shown in .

elements.content: (a) Structural properties of the [Cu2(C2O4)3 2–] n framework. Color code: Cu1, plum; Cu2, lavender; O, red; C, gray. Dark black lines indicate elongated Cu–O bonds on CuO6 octahedra. (b) Arrangement of oxalate-bridged magnetic interactions between the Cu atoms. Dashed black and green lines are magnetic interactions between metal atoms.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Structural properties of the [Cu2(C2O4)3 2-] n  framework. Color code: Cu1, plum; Cu2, lavender; O, red; C, gray. Dark black lines indicate elongated Cu-O bonds on CuO6 octahedra. (b) Arrangement of oxalate-bridged magnetic interactions between the Cu atoms. Dashed black and green lines are magnetic interactions between metal atoms.

elements.content: The magnetic configuration and interactions of the Cu spins within the hyperhoneycomb lattice are postulated from an orbital analysis and the site separation distances. The strongest antiferromagnetic (AF) interaction with a magnitude of 200 K or more is expected for J 1a. The interaction J 1c is also expected to be strongly AF at around 60 K and J 1b is expected to be AF with magnitude up to 25 K. The interaction J′ should be much weaker than all the other interactions due to the longer Cu2···Cu2 distance, giving the order J 1c > J 1b > J′. The resulting magnetic lattice can be viewed as a quasi-honeycomb lattice that has been stretched in one direction by inserting strongly coupled Cu2 dimers into the b-axis links and the effective magnetic coordination number z is 3 for Cu1 and 2 for Cu2. From the evolution of the structural parameters with temperature above 93 K, a gradual transition around 150 K is observed (a). A sharp disorder–order transition of one ethylene group on one of the ammonium cations is also observed at 165 K, revealed by both DSC and dielectric measurements. The copper-oxalate-framework remains unchanged across these transitions and the Jahn–Teller distortion of the CuO6 octahedra is smoothly enhanced through this region as temperature decreases and shows saturation below 120 K ().
elements.clean_text: The magnetic configuration and interactions of the Cu spins within the hyperhoneycomb lattice are postulated from an orbital analysis and the site separation distances. The strongest antiferromagnetic (AF) interaction with a magnitude of 200 K or more is expected for J 1a. The interaction J 1c is also expected to be strongly AF at around 60 K and J 1b is expected to be AF with magnitude up to 25 K. The interaction J' should be much weaker than all the other interactions due to the longer Cu2⋅⋅⋅Cu2 distance, giving the order J 1c > J 1b > J'. The resulting magnetic lattice can be viewed as a quasi-honeycomb lattice that has been stretched in one direction by inserting strongly coupled Cu2 dimers into the b-axis links and the effective magnetic coordination number z is 3 for Cu1 and 2 for Cu2. From the evolution of the structural parameters with temperature above 93 K, a gradual transition around 150 K is observed (a). A sharp disorder-order transition of one ethylene group on one of the ammonium cations is also observed at 165 K, revealed by both DSC and dielectric measurements. The copper-oxalate-framework remains unchanged across these transitions and the Jahn-Teller distortion of the CuO6 octahedra is smoothly enhanced through this region as temperature decreases and shows saturation below 120 K ().

elements.content: Structural parameters versus T from 375 to 93 K: Cu···Cu distances across the oxalate bridges (a) and unit cell parameters (b).
elements.clean_text: 2  Structural parameters versus T from 375 to 93 K: Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances across the oxalate bridges (a) and unit cell parameters (b).

elements.content: No λ-peak was observed in specific heat measurements from 120 K down to 2 K, indicating the absence of further structural or magnetic transition. The finite intercept of C p/T () extrapolated to T = 0 corresponds to a linear coefficient γ = 36(2) mJ K–2 mol–1, which can be compared to the linear coefficients reported for the triangular lattice QSL systems Ba3CuSb2O9 (43 mJ K–2 mol–1), κ-(BEDT-TTF)2Cu2(CN)3 (10–20 mJ K–2 mol–1) and EtMe3Sb­[Pd­(dmit)2]2 (20 mJ K–2 mol–1).
elements.clean_text: No λ-peak was observed in specific heat measurements from 120 K down to 2 K, indicating the absence of further structural or magnetic transition. The finite intercept of C p/T () extrapolated to T = 0 corresponds to a linear coefficient γ = 36(2) mJ K-2 mol-1, which can be compared to the linear coefficients reported for the triangular lattice QSL systems Ba3CuSb2O9 (43 mJ K-2 mol-1), κ-(BEDT-TTF)2Cu2(CN)3 (10-20 mJ K-2 mol-1) and EtMe3Sb[Pd(dmit)2]2 (20 mJ K-2 mol-1).

elements.content: Specific heat normalized to one mole of Cu2+ spins plotted as C p/T versusT 2 and the corresponding fit. The inset shows C p versus T over a wider T range.
elements.clean_text: 3  Specific heat normalized to one mole of Cu2+ spins plotted as C p/T versusT 2 and the corresponding fit. The inset shows C p versus T over a wider T range.

elements.content: The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility measured at 1000 Oe was fitted to the Curie–Weiss law with temperature-dependent Weiss parameter θ (). The obtained Curie constant C = 0.475(3) cm3 mol–1 corresponds to all of the S = 1/2 Cu2+ in the structure. A broad transition in the θ value takes place around 150 K, corresponding to the broad region of structural relaxation (). The magnitude of the Weiss parameter increases from −93(2) K at 250 K to −183(2) K at 50 K. This is consistent with the strongest interactions between metal atoms J 1a and J 1c increasing with decreasing temperature (a). An effective exchange coupling parameter J below 50 K can be estimated from J = 2θ /z taking z as the average coordination of magnetic ions in the lattice, giving a magnitude of 144 K.
elements.clean_text: The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility measured at 1000 Oe was fitted to the Curie-Weiss law with temperature-dependent Weiss parameter θ (). The obtained Curie constant C = 0.475(3) cm3 mol-1 corresponds to all of the S = 1/2 Cu2+ in the structure. A broad transition in the θ value takes place around 150 K, corresponding to the broad region of structural relaxation (). The magnitude of the Weiss parameter increases from -93(2) K at 250 K to -183(2) K at 50 K. This is consistent with the strongest interactions between metal atoms J 1a and J 1c increasing with decreasing temperature (a). An effective exchange coupling parameter J below 50 K can be estimated from J = 2θ /z taking z as the average coordination of magnetic ions in the lattice, giving a magnitude of 144 K.

elements.content: The χ-vs-T plot () shows a broad and weak peak around 30 K that indicates short-range antiferromagnetic correlations, as commonly observed in low-dimensional magnets. Below 10 K, the susceptibility increases rapidly. However, no bifurcation was observed from ZFC/FC/RM measurements and no λ-peak was observed from specific heat data above 2 K, so this increase does not reflect magnetic LRO. It can be assigned to the paramagnetic response of orphan spins, as often found in frustrated spin systems, corresponding here to 0.6% of the Cu2+ spins. After correction for this paramagnetic Curie term, the low temperature limit of the intrinsic susceptibility is estimated to be χ0 = 0.0020(2) cm3 mol–1.
elements.clean_text: The χ-vs-T plot () shows a broad and weak peak around 30 K that indicates short-range antiferromagnetic correlations, as commonly observed in low-dimensional magnets. Below 10 K, the susceptibility increases rapidly. However, no bifurcation was observed from ZFC/FC/RM measurements and no λ-peak was observed from specific heat data above 2 K, so this increase does not reflect magnetic LRO. It can be assigned to the paramagnetic response of orphan spins, as often found in frustrated spin systems, corresponding here to 0.6% of the Cu2+ spins. After correction for this paramagnetic Curie term, the low temperature limit of the intrinsic susceptibility is estimated to be χ0 = 0.0020(2) cm3 mol-1.

elements.content: Muon spin relaxation (μSR) measurements can check for magnetic ordering in a candidate QSL. From the zero field μSR taken down to 60 mK (), it is seen that on cooling the relaxation smoothly crosses over from a Gaussian associated with nuclear moments to a Lorentzian reflecting fluctuating electronic spins. No oscillations due to static magnetism were observed and the electronic spins remain fluctuating down to 60 mK, consistent with a QSL state and indicating a frustration factor above 3000.
elements.clean_text: Muon spin relaxation (μSR) measurements can check for magnetic ordering in a candidate QSL. From the zero field μSR taken down to 60 mK (), it is seen that on cooling the relaxation smoothly crosses over from a Gaussian associated with nuclear moments to a Lorentzian reflecting fluctuating electronic spins. No oscillations due to static magnetism were observed and the electronic spins remain fluctuating down to 60 mK, consistent with a QSL state and indicating a frustration factor above 3000.

elements.content: Evolution of the ZF-μSR time spectra between 200 K and 60 mK measured using the EMU spectrometer at ISIS.
elements.clean_text: 4  Evolution of the ZF-μSR time spectra between 200 K and 60 mK measured using the EMU spectrometer at ISIS.

elements.content: The character of the QSL state can be tested by taking the dimensionless Wilson ratio R W = 4­(πk B/(gμB))2/(3μ0) χ0/γ. In an RVB QSL, one expects R W < 1 and we find R W = 0.19, which is comparable to the value 0.15 for the 2D kagome QSL Herbertsmithite () and inconsistent with the large value R W = 2 of the ideal 1D S = 1/2 Heisenberg AF chain. This indicates a 2D QSL and thus implies the presence of significant b axis coupling of the Cu1 spins via the Cu2 dimers.
elements.clean_text: The character of the QSL state can be tested by taking the dimensionless Wilson ratio R W = 4(πk B/(gμB))2/(3μ0) χ0/γ. In an RVB QSL, one expects R W < 1 and we find R W = 0.19, which is comparable to the value 0.15 for the 2D kagome QSL Herbertsmithite () and inconsistent with the large value R W = 2 of the ideal 1D S = 1/2 Heisenberg AF chain. This indicates a 2D QSL and thus implies the presence of significant b axis coupling of the Cu1 spins via the Cu2 dimers.

Properties of the present system are compared with some other frustrated systems in . The only previously reported hyperhoneycomb magnetic compound β-Li2IrO3 shows magnetic ordering at 38 K, so the present oxalate compound is the first example of a QSL obtained from a 3D hyperhoneycomb lattice. The spatial anisotropy of the magnetic interactions induced here by a combination of Jahn–Teller distortion and partial dimerization leads to a novel magnetic lattice that can be represented as a 2D quasi-honeycomb. Further experimental and computational studies are under way to better establish the size and nature of the relevant interactions and excitations.
elements.clean_text: Properties of the present system are compared with some other frustrated systems in . The only previously reported hyperhoneycomb magnetic compound β-Li2IrO3 shows magnetic ordering at 38 K, so the present oxalate compound is the first example of a QSL obtained from a 3D hyperhoneycomb lattice. The spatial anisotropy of the magnetic interactions induced here by a combination of Jahn-Teller distortion and partial dimerization leads to a novel magnetic lattice that can be represented as a 2D quasi-honeycomb. Further experimental and computational studies are under way to better establish the size and nature of the relevant interactions and excitations.

elements.content: In general terms, it has become clear that the oxalate bridge, besides being an important cornerstone for producing various molecular magnets, also provides a new pathway for obtaining QSLs from metal-oxalate-framework compounds.
elements.clean_text: In general terms, it has become clear that the oxalate bridge, besides being an important cornerstone for producing various molecular magnets, also provides a new pathway for obtaining QSLs from metal-oxalate-framework compounds.

Lattice types: K is kagome, T is triangular, H is honeycomb, HK is hyperkagome, HH is hyperhoneycomb; z is the average magnetic coordination number of the spin unit; D is the effective dimension of the magnetic lattice; θ is the Weiss temperature; T c is the spin freezing or ordering temperature; f = |θ |/T c is the Ramirez frustration parameter; R W is the Wilson ratio. For the two copper oxalate compounds, the reduction in z and D by Jahn–Teller distortion is indicated. For Ba3CuSb2O9, it should be noted that only 50% of the triangular lattice sites are occupied by Cu2+ spins.
elements.clean_text:
The authors declare no competing financial interest.

Lattice types: K is kagome, T is triangular, H is honeycomb, HK is hyperkagome, HH is hyperhoneycomb; z is the average magnetic coordination number of the spin unit; D is the effective dimension of the magnetic lattice; θ is the Weiss temperature; T c is the spin freezing or ordering temperature; f = |θ |/T c is the Ramirez frustration parameter; R W is the Wilson ratio. For the two copper oxalate compounds, the reduction in z and D by Jahn-Teller distortion is indicated. For Ba3CuSb2O9, it should be noted that only 50% of the triangular lattice sites are occupied by Cu2+ spins.

cln_elements.content:
No λ-peak was observed in specific heat measurements from 120 K down to 2 K, indicating the absence of further structural or magnetic transition. The finite intercept of C p/T () extrapolated to T = 0 corresponds to a linear coefficient γ = 36(2) mJ K–2 mol–1, which can be compared to the linear coefficients reported for the triangular lattice QSL systems Ba3CuSb2O9 (43 mJ K–2 mol–1), κ-(BEDT-TTF)2Cu2(CN)3 (10–20 mJ K–2 mol–1) and EtMe3Sb­[Pd­(dmit)2]2 (20 mJ K–2 mol–1).

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility measured at 1000 Oe was fitted to the Curie–Weiss law with temperature-dependent Weiss parameter θ (). The obtained Curie constant C = 0.475(3) cm3 mol–1 corresponds to all of the S = 1/2 Cu2+ in the structure. A broad transition in the θ value takes place around 150 K, corresponding to the broad region of structural relaxation (). The magnitude of the Weiss parameter increases from −93(2) K at 250 K to −183(2) K at 50 K. This is consistent with the strongest interactions between metal atoms J 1a and J 1c increasing with decreasing temperature (a). An effective exchange coupling parameter J below 50 K can be estimated from J = 2θ /z taking z as the average coordination of magnetic ions in the lattice, giving a magnitude of 144 K.

The χ-vs-T plot () shows a broad and weak peak around 30 K that indicates short-range antiferromagnetic correlations, as commonly observed in low-dimensional magnets. Below 10 K, the susceptibility increases rapidly. However, no bifurcation was observed from ZFC/FC/RM measurements and no λ-peak was observed from specific heat data above 2 K, so this increase does not reflect magnetic LRO. It can be assigned to the paramagnetic response of orphan spins, as often found in frustrated spin systems, corresponding here to 0.6% of the Cu2+ spins. After correction for this paramagnetic Curie term, the low temperature limit of the intrinsic susceptibility is estimated to be χ0 = 0.0020(2) cm3 mol–1.

Muon spin relaxation (μSR) measurements can check for magnetic ordering in a candidate QSL. From the zero field μSR taken down to 60 mK (), it is seen that on cooling the relaxation smoothly crosses over from a Gaussian associated with nuclear moments to a Lorentzian reflecting fluctuating electronic spins. No oscillations due to static magnetism were observed and the electronic spins remain fluctuating down to 60 mK, consistent with a QSL state and indicating a frustration factor above 3000.

Properties of the present system are compared with some other frustrated systems in . The only previously reported hyperhoneycomb magnetic compound β-Li2IrO3 shows magnetic ordering at 38 K, so the present oxalate compound is the first example of a QSL obtained from a 3D hyperhoneycomb lattice. The spatial anisotropy of the magnetic interactions induced here by a combination of Jahn–Teller distortion and partial dimerization leads to a novel magnetic lattice that can be represented as a 2D quasi-honeycomb. Further experimental and computational studies are under way to better establish the size and nature of the relevant interactions and excitations.
cln_elements.clean_text:
No λ-peak was observed in specific heat measurements from 120 K down to 2 K, indicating the absence of further structural or magnetic transition. The finite intercept of C p/T () extrapolated to T = 0 corresponds to a linear coefficient γ = 36(2) mJ K-2 mol-1, which can be compared to the linear coefficients reported for the triangular lattice QSL systems Ba3CuSb2O9 (43 mJ K-2 mol-1), κ-(BEDT-TTF)2Cu2(CN)3 (10-20 mJ K-2 mol-1) and EtMe3Sb[Pd(dmit)2]2 (20 mJ K-2 mol-1).

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility measured at 1000 Oe was fitted to the Curie-Weiss law with temperature-dependent Weiss parameter θ (). The obtained Curie constant C = 0.475(3) cm3 mol-1 corresponds to all of the S = 1/2 Cu2+ in the structure. A broad transition in the θ value takes place around 150 K, corresponding to the broad region of structural relaxation (). The magnitude of the Weiss parameter increases from -93(2) K at 250 K to -183(2) K at 50 K. This is consistent with the strongest interactions between metal atoms J 1a and J 1c increasing with decreasing temperature (a). An effective exchange coupling parameter J below 50 K can be estimated from J = 2θ /z taking z as the average coordination of magnetic ions in the lattice, giving a magnitude of 144 K.

The χ-vs-T plot () shows a broad and weak peak around 30 K that indicates short-range antiferromagnetic correlations, as commonly observed in low-dimensional magnets. Below 10 K, the susceptibility increases rapidly. However, no bifurcation was observed from ZFC/FC/RM measurements and no λ-peak was observed from specific heat data above 2 K, so this increase does not reflect magnetic LRO. It can be assigned to the paramagnetic response of orphan spins, as often found in frustrated spin systems, corresponding here to 0.6% of the Cu2+ spins. After correction for this paramagnetic Curie term, the low temperature limit of the intrinsic susceptibility is estimated to be χ0 = 0.0020(2) cm3 mol-1.

Muon spin relaxation (μSR) measurements can check for magnetic ordering in a candidate QSL. From the zero field μSR taken down to 60 mK (), it is seen that on cooling the relaxation smoothly crosses over from a Gaussian associated with nuclear moments to a Lorentzian reflecting fluctuating electronic spins. No oscillations due to static magnetism were observed and the electronic spins remain fluctuating down to 60 mK, consistent with a QSL state and indicating a frustration factor above 3000.

Properties of the present system are compared with some other frustrated systems in . The only previously reported hyperhoneycomb magnetic compound β-Li2IrO3 shows magnetic ordering at 38 K, so the present oxalate compound is the first example of a QSL obtained from a 3D hyperhoneycomb lattice. The spatial anisotropy of the magnetic interactions induced here by a combination of Jahn-Teller distortion and partial dimerization leads to a novel magnetic lattice that can be represented as a 2D quasi-honeycomb. Further experimental and computational studies are under way to better establish the size and nature of the relevant interactions and excitations.

data: This model's maximum context length is 4097 tokens. However, your messages resulted in 4374 tokens. Please reduce the length of the messages.

cln_elements.content: (a) Structural properties of the [Cu2(C2O4)3 2–] n framework. Color code: Cu1, plum; Cu2, lavender; O, red; C, gray. Dark black lines indicate elongated Cu–O bonds on CuO6 octahedra. (b) Arrangement of oxalate-bridged magnetic interactions between the Cu atoms. Dashed black and green lines are magnetic interactions between metal atoms.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Structural properties of the [Cu2(C2O4)3 2-] n  framework. Color code: Cu1, plum; Cu2, lavender; O, red; C, gray. Dark black lines indicate elongated Cu-O bonds on CuO6 octahedra. (b) Arrangement of oxalate-bridged magnetic interactions between the Cu atoms. Dashed black and green lines are magnetic interactions between metal atoms.

cln_elements.content: Structural parameters versus T from 375 to 93 K: Cu···Cu distances across the oxalate bridges (a) and unit cell parameters (b).
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Structural parameters versus T from 375 to 93 K: Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances across the oxalate bridges (a) and unit cell parameters (b).

cln_elements.content: Specific heat normalized to one mole of Cu2+ spins plotted as C p/T versusT 2 and the corresponding fit. The inset shows C p versus T over a wider T range.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Specific heat normalized to one mole of Cu2+ spins plotted as C p/T versusT 2 and the corresponding fit. The inset shows C p versus T over a wider T range.

cln_elements.content: Evolution of the ZF-μSR time spectra between 200 K and 60 mK measured using the EMU spectrometer at ISIS.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  Evolution of the ZF-μSR time spectra between 200 K and 60 mK measured using the EMU spectrometer at ISIS.

metadata.title:
Quantum
Spin Liquid from a Three-Dimensional Copper-Oxalate
Framework
